data.title: Pretty good Brazilian
data.text:
This is a modest restaurant in terms of setting but the food is good and feels authentically Brazilian.  The caiprinha (national drink of Brazil) is super tasty, a lime and rum specialty that is tasty but a bit overpriced at $13 for a glass of mostly ice.

The food is better.  The Coxhina (chicken croquettes) were really tasty and went nicely with the super spicy pepper sauce that is on each table.  I was very pleased with the Bobó de Galinha, a pleasantly spiced stew with flavors of coconut and and cashews marinating tender chunks of chicken.  My companion's Feijoada Completa (beef, pork, and bean stew) was also good but I think my chicken was easily better.

A nice place to check out if you are in the Haye's valley neighborhood.

data.title: Authentic
data.text: Happened in to this place at Happy Hour. Very busy. Good appetizers and drinks. Not very large in size but large in flavors.

data.title: Brazilian comfort
data.text: This is a comfortable, friendly neighborhood restaurant. I had the basic white wine which was lovely and bright, coconut rice (rich and heavy) and a fish chowder, excellent. My husband's chowder in a squash made a great presentation. The croquettes were smaller than on the streets of Rio but light and fresh. All in all, a good choice. We had reservations but they weren't needed for a Thursday night. Although there were other diners, it wasn't noisy. Clean restrooms.

data.title: Friendly wait-staff, portions a little too large and over-sauced
data.text:
The food had great flavor, and was clearly authentic. My partner found his salmon to be over-sauced and a little too citrusy. My feijoada was tasty, but also deconstructed. I ate maybe half of what they served, and I still felt like I overate. 

The drink menu is amazing, I will say! Creative mixed drinks and a solid (if short) wine list. 

The atmosphere is bright and cozy. Good for a group of friends wanting a casual (not loud) night on the town. It is also close to the Symphony/Opera/Jazz Center in Hayes Valley.

Recommended.

data.title: Loved our meal!
data.text: My husband and I recently shared a wonderful birthday meal at this restaurant. The drinks (you have to try their caipirinha!), appetizers (croquettes, soooo goood!) and our main courses (picanha for me, ribs for my husband) and the yummiest desert I've had in a long time (guava flan) were amazing. Service was also amazing, and our waiter Tairo was super helpful, personable and extremely nice!

data.title: Brazil in our backyard
data.text: Wonderful environment to truly feel like you're in Brazil. Mojitos and Caipirinhas are a must have. Love the yucca fries, but really everything was delicious.

data.title: Excellent food and service !
data.text: Visiting from out of town and decided to celebrate my wife's birthday at Mina's after reviewing the menu.  The food and service was excellent, and the price very reasonable.  The staff prepared a fantastic cake to celebrate my wife's birthday.  I would highly recommend Mina's.

data.title: Don't judge by the cover
data.text: Went with friends for dinner. Food was excellent and service was great. Restaurant is actually pretty fancy but can't tell from the outside. Good size menu with a lot of unique dishes. I had the freijoada with a passion fruit drink (it was actual passion fruit with seeds!) and a caramel flan. Fresh,tasty food in a great atmosphere. Bill came out to around $50 with tip

data.title: Excellent Food
data.text: 6 if us had dinner here. Staff very friendly and service was good. Food was excellent baby ribs delicious fell off the bone. Great choice of cocktails. Definitely recommend.

data.title: Travelzoo $20 Brunch for $30 worth of food and mimosas
data.text:
Travelzoo offers a great deal here.

We went for brunch time and was gladly welcomed by the live Bossa band.  I definitely would recommend the feijoada.  The humble flavors and hearty dish tastes so pleasant.  Other diners referred to the dish tasting like home. My boyfriend also ordered the Bife Acebolado which was also tasty. So if you are in the Bay area and are craving Brazilian food, definitely come here!

data.title: Authentic Brazilian Food at Reasonable Prices
data.text:
I have been to Brazil many times but never to the state of Minas Gerais. The style of cuisine is described as "farmhouse", whatever that means. Anyway, the room was small and comfortable feeling, with yellow walls and big windows facing the street. The service was friendly and descriptions of the food were eagerly offered by our waiter.

Have I gotten this far without mentioning the caipirinhas? They have specially flavored ones (watermelon was highlighted this evening) but the regular old lime ones contained lots of cachaca and were delicious.

The menu contained a selection of traditional Brazilian dishes, and I had to try the feijoada. It came in a small cassoulet dish, with rice, a slice of pineapple and manioc on the side. It was both delicious and authentic! My wife was equally enthusiastic about the bobo de galinha, chicken with yucca sauce sprinkled with cashews. She began with a hearts of palm salad, huge and very good, and I started with fried calamari, which were OK.

Then a couple more caipirinhas for dessert. The waiter got our check mixed up with someone else's, and it took him 10 mins to straighten it out, but he was apologetic, and was easily forgiven because this restaurant offers something rare in San Francisco, modest prices for the quality of the food.

I am looking forward to my next visit. Cheaper than a flight to Brazil!

data.title: Great
data.text: For us it was the "closure" of a 2 weeks trip to San Francisco. Great food, nice employees! We had salmon with passion fruit sauce and the Feijoada... Place to go! 👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼

data.title: Very nice little place with excellent food.
data.text: Great little traditional Brazilian restaurant.  NOT a churrascaria (grilled steakhouse), but rather original and unique tasty meals and touches.

data.title: Good Brazilian food
data.text: I went to Minas before going to the theater.  The food was fresh and served hot.  My server was wonderful and very friendly.  It was a great value and good food.

data.title: A great end to a great day
data.text:
Food was delicious, I had the Costolenhas,
bbqed pork spare ribs marinated in guava paste, absolutely yummy. The meat just fell off the bones in your mouth. My wife had the feijoada, a pork stew.
We had started with Caparinhas, which were very good and refreshing.
Dessert was a passion fruit mousse with something like Panna cotta.
Wine was reasonable, we had a Spanish Garnacha.
Service OK, and very friendly, but they seemed have trouble keeping up demands on their services.

data.title: Good but nothing special
data.text: Very nice people working here,  food was good and just good. Reasonably priced for SF. The little disappointment was the smell in the restaurant, sorry but you need to solve it.

data.title: Birthday lunch
data.text: I'm  a waitress. I had gift card for this restaurant so I decided to used on my birthday for lunch I took my kids and grandma I drove 45 minutes ;the food was good loved the dessert .the service was bad, not friendly  I felted uncomfortable to be there the waiter charge gratuity because he thought that I wasn't going to tip him good my husband added extra tip  to the check but not kids friendly

data.title: Off The Beaten Track
data.text: My son and I started by sharing the Bolinho de Bacalhau, Fried Croquettes which was very nice with sauce that was difficult to use. Then we had a very nice bean soup that was serviced with a very hot sauce. I had the Frutos do Mar Tropical which was served in a Pineapple. This was very nice but I could not understand having it in a Pineapple. My son had the Moqueca de Peixe which also was with fish which looked like it would have been a better value. We were also impressed with the nice and friendly service.

data.title: Brazilian restaurant is heavy on the sauces, but light on the pocket book
data.text:
Minas Brazilian Restaurant & Cachacaria is a relative newcomer to the Hayes Valley restaurant scene.  It occupies the same location as a previous Brazilian restaurant.  Although it obviously is trying very hard to be special and really authentic, in my opinion Minas is unfortunately not quite as good as its predecessor.  Nevertheless, it is not a bad place, and extremely reasonably priced in comparison with other restaurants in the area.  You can get a very good meal for not much money here; it just won't be top flight Brazilian food.  
On a recent visit, my wife and I enjoyed our appetizers very much –– I highly recommend the very popular fried calamari, which is better than average.  The problem is with the main courses.  My wife had the Bobó de Galinha, a traditional sautéed chicken dish cooked in a coconut-yucca sauce.  I had the Moqueca de Peixe, a fish stew cooked in a sauce of tomatoes, red and yellow bell peppers, and coconut milk.  Both were served in small, oval cassoulet-style terrines.  Although both were quite tasty, they suffered from swimming in too much sauce.  Generally, I love sauce, but in this case, as Larry David would have said on "Curb Your Enthusiasm," it was just a bit "too saucy."  The dessert, a Brazilian-style Pudin de Coco, or coconut flan, was tasty, but quite heavy. Between the two of us we could barely finish it.  
Bottom line:  even though the food wasn't at all bad, we were both a bit disappointed.  Having been to Brazil and enjoyed the food there very much, and remembering the quality of the former restaurant in this same location, we were forced to conclude that Minas is just not quite as good as the real thing.  
Nevertheless, the price was right (by San Francisco standards, of course).  No question, this place has an economically priced menu.  And we found the service to be extremely friendly, helpful and prompt. So if you don't care whether or not the food is the most authentic and best Brazilian style cuisine you could find, you can still enjoy this restaurant for its undeniably tasty dishes and very economical prices.

data.title: Quick Dinner but tasty
data.text: Stopped here on my first night in SF this trip.  I didn't have reservations, so I was first told that I could have a table but needed to finish in about 45 minutes.  Then I was told I could have a table with no rush.  Either way, I ordered a salad and the black bean and pork stew.  Both came out quickly, but I wasn't rushed.  Along with a glass of wine, I had an enjoyable yet quick dinner.  The stew was very tasty, and the sauteed greens, orange slice, and farofa were all delicious sides to the stew!
